to level the barriers of nations. ⁴Two languages again were more and more taking the place of a Babel of tongues: the prevalence of Greek in the East may be estimated from the extent of its use among even a race so tenacious of nationality as the Hebrews¹ ; while, in the West, Latin, already prevalent in Gaul, making the vernacular forgotten in many parts of Spain 2, and generally spoken also in Pannonia ⁸, was not wholly lost even by Rome’s bitterest enemies 4; and, as the official lan- guage of the whole empne, had some hold even in the East ⁵.

Again, though Tiberius probably imitated the reserve of Augustus in bestowing the ‘ civitas ⁶3 ’ yet even this great equalisation of privilege must have been steadily extending itself. By the manumission of slaves, which, in spite of checks imposed upon it, must have been constant, any Roman could call into existence those who at a stroke of the wand succeeded to most⁷, and whose sons would succeed to all, civic privileges. Many a Roman pauper by transplantation to a colony became there the parent of a prosperous civic family. Many an auxiliary soldier, already habituated to Roman. customs by service under the standards, received the civitas on his discharge ⁸, and his sons might serve and rise in the ranks of the legions and thus lay the foundation of a career of honour.

Lastly, in spite of the vast diversity of tolerated religions,’some traces of common religious ideas begin to develope themselves. The restora- tion of religion had formed a great part of the policy of Augustus, and his aspirations are devoutly seconded by the poets of his court⁹. Besides the rebuilding or restoration of almost every temple in the city ¹⁶, he had endeavoured to bring home religion to the mass of the people by a kind of parochial system, in the worship of the ‘ Lares compitales ' at the 300 chapels1¹ instituted in the various vici, under the ministration of their freedmen priests (‘Augustales '), and superintendence of the ‘ vico· magistri ¹²!
